ğŸŒ¤ï¸ Seasonal Climate Fits

Many ecological and epidemiological models benefit from representing climate variablesâ€”such as temperature and photoperiodâ€”as smooth periodic functions.

climecol provides two complementary utilities for this purpose:

- fit_seasonal_temp() â€“ fits sinusoidal or user-defined periodic models to mean daily temperature, averaged across years.
- fit_seasonal_photo() â€“ fits similar models to daylength (photoperiod) data, either supplied directly or generated via photoperiod_year().

Both functions:

- Aggregate daily data by day-of-year and compute the mean seasonal cycle.
- Fit one or more parametric periodic functions using nls().
- Return AIC and RÂ² metrics to compare goodness of fit.
- Optionally plot observed versus fitted cycles.
	
Example 1 â€” Fitting temperature cycles

```{r}
res_temp <- fit_seasonal_temp(
  weather_nl,
  funcs = c("sin1", "sin2"),
  plot  = TRUE
)
res_temp$metrics
res_temp$plot
```

Example 2 â€” Fitting photoperiod cycles

```{r}
res_photo <- fit_seasonal_photo(
  location = "St John's",
  years    = c(2023, 2024),
  funcs    = c("sin1", "sin2"),
  plot     = TRUE
)
res_photo$metrics
res_photo$plot
```

Example 3 â€” Supplying a custom periodic model

```{r}
res_photo_custom <- fit_seasonal_photo(
  location = "St John's",
  years = c(2023, 2024),
  funcs = "sin1",
  custom = list(
    cos1 = list(
      formula = avg_photo ~ a + b * cos(2*pi*day_of_year/365),
      start   = list(a = 12, b = 6)
    )
  ),
  plot = TRUE
)
res_photo_custom$metrics
```

Suggested applications

- Representing smooth seasonal forcing in climate-driven mosquito or disease models.
